nodes.bodyText: Repeated code (also applies to endMsOrDefault) -- please see comment on removing startMs and endMs.

More specifically, when we use condition ? a : b, it tries to find the common denominator between a type and b type. In the below case, the common type denominator is primitive long. That means it will try to unbox defaultIfMissing which could be null in this case.
parameterString == null ? defaultIfMissing : Long.parseLong(...)
Right. This one works since Long.valueOf(...) return Long instead of long. So defaultIfMissing does not get unboxed

Having separate functions for startMs and startMsOrDefault (same issue for end) seems a little redundant (e.g. see code repetition for parseParamAsLong(request, START_MS_PARAM) between these functions).
I wonder if we can make it more concise by dropping endMs and startMs functions. Their callers can call startMsOrDefault and endMsOrDefault with null as the default parameter.

For consistency of the parameter name for missing default values defaultEndMs -> defaultIfMissing.
Also, can we make the return type and the type of the default parameter Long? Clearly, if the response is null, it would only be possible via a null default parameter passed to this function.
OK, that makes sense
2017 -> 2020 (i.e. date of creation)

nodes.bodyText: Is it acceptable for these mocked responses to be called anyTimes? Is it possible to be more specific?
Sure. I made it specific
Why don't we use the .longValue() of start and endMs?
Can we avoid hardcoding test values and move them to static variables?
Sure
Should other Long parameters in this class also use of this function for parsing -- e.g. EXECUTION_PROGRESS_CHECK_INTERVAL_MS_PARAM?

nodes.bodyText:
(Applies to other similar uses in this test):
Nit: times(1) -> once() -- i.e. calling one time is special :)

(One more similar use above):
Nit: This is a map with a single element -- should we use a singletonMap? -- i.e.
    Map<String, String[]> paramMap = Collections.singletonMap(ParameterUtils.EXECUTION_PROGRESS_CHECK_INTERVAL_MS_PARAM,
                                                              new String[]{ParameterUtils.EXECUTION_PROGRESS_CHECK_INTERVAL_MS_PARAM});

Looks the mocks are not verified in tests -- i.e. there is no actual verification of whether mock functions are called or how many times they are called.
Can we call EasyMock.verify(...) for each test after mocks are replayed and actual calls are made?

(There are other similar uses in this test):
This function takes Object... as input; hence, we can pass all mocks in a single call rather than sequential calls.
